misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect inclusive/exclusive bounds for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The student uses a strict greater-than condition for the A range, which misclassifies boundary values (e.g., a grade of 90 is treated as B instead of A).
misconceptions.student_belief: If I write `if (grade > 90)` for A and `else if (grade >= 80)` for B, then the ranges match the specification A: 90–100, B: 80–89.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To include 90 in the A range (90–100), the condition must be `grade >= 90`. With an if-else chain, using `if (grade >= 90)` followed by `else if (grade >= 80)` yields A: 90–100 and B: 80–89, because any grade 90 or above is already caught by the first condition.
symptoms: A grade of exactly 90 would produce letter grade B instead of A.
The effective ranges become: A: (90, ∞), B: [80, 90], C: [70, 80), D: [60, 70), F: else.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about inclusive vs exclusive inequalities and how an if-else chain partitions numeric ranges. The student may be thinking in terms of '> 90' implying '90–100' without considering that 90 itself is excluded.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Adjust the conditions so that the A range is `if (grade >= 90)` and keep B as `else if (grade >= 80)`. Then test your code with boundary values (80, 89, 90, 100) to confirm they fall in the intended ranges.
related_concepts: Designing numeric ranges with if-else chains
Off-by-one and boundary errors in conditions
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The inequality pattern (`grade > 90` followed by `grade >= 80`) systematically shifts the boundary at 90, clearly contradicting the specified ranges.

evidence.note: The A range uses `grade > 90`, excluding 90, while B uses `grade >= 80`, causing 90 to be classified as B instead of A.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect Boundary Check for Inclusive Grade Range
misconceptions.description: The student uses a strict inequality (>) instead of an inclusive inequality (>=) when checking the boundary condition for the 'A' grade range (90-100). This results in the boundary value (90) falling into the next lower grade category ('B').
misconceptions.student_belief: For a range that starts at 90, comparison using `grade > 90` is sufficient, or that 90 belongs to the next category defined by `grade >= 80`.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To correctly categorize a grade of 90 into the 'A' range, the condition should be `grade >= 90`. The use of strict inequality (`> 90`) incorrectly excludes the lowest value of the desired range.
symptoms: A grade of 90 receives a 'B' instead of an 'A'
Boundary values are misclassified
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion regarding the application of strict vs. inclusive inequality operators in high-to-low cascading conditional statements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Since the 'A' grade starts at 90, make sure your condition includes the number 90. Use the greater-than-or-equal-to operator (>=).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `grade > 90` where `grade >= 90` is required for correctness based on the problem statement 'A: 90-100'.

evidence.note: The 'A' grade comparison uses strict inequality (> 90), incorrectly excluding 90 from the 'A' grade.

misconceptions.name: Mixing Solutions/Extraneous Code
misconceptions.description: The student's submission for the Grade Calculator problem contains the complete, executable solution for an unrelated geometric problem (Distance Between Points) prior to the required logic. This demonstrates a failure to isolate and submit only the required code.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable to combine solutions for multiple problems into a single execution file, possibly because they believe all previous work must be present.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Submissions should typically contain only the code dedicated to solving the specified problem, ensuring clean execution flow and class structure appropriate for the task (ideally having a relevant class name).
symptoms: The program executes non-required input prompts and distance calculations
The class name is `DistanceBetweenPoints` but contains the `Grade Calculator` logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely developed solutions for multiple problems sequentially within the same `main` method and failed to remove or comment out the unnecessary code when preparing the final submission for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: For individual submissions, ensure your code only performs the logic necessary for that specific question. Remove or comment out any extraneous, unrelated code blocks.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: A large, unrelated logic block is present and executes before the required code, strongly suggesting a copy-paste without cleanup.

evidence.note: The entire body of the main method is dedicated to an unrelated task (Distance calculation) before initiating the Grade Calculator code.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect boundary condition for grade A
misconceptions.description: Student uses strict greater-than (>) instead of greater-than-or-equal-to (>=) for the upper boundary of grade A, causing a boundary value error where a grade of exactly 90 is incorrectly classified.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the condition `grade > 90` correctly captures the range 90-100 for letter grade A.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct condition should be `grade >= 90` to include the boundary value 90 itself. The range 90-100 includes both endpoints, so >= is required.
symptoms: Grade of 90 would be classified as B instead of A
Off-by-one error in boundary logic
Inconsistency with rubric specification (A: 90-100)
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between strict inequality (>) and inclusive inequality (>=). The student may have thought 'greater than 90' means 'starting from 90' when it actually means 'starting from 91'. This is a common mistake when translating verbal ranges to code conditions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change `if (grade > 90)` to `if (grade >= 90)`. Remember: when a range includes an endpoint (like '90-100'), use >= or <= rather than > or <.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence. The code explicitly shows `grade > 90` on line 19, and the problem statement clearly specifies 'A: 90-100', making this a definite boundary error. This would produce incorrect output for the edge case of grade = 90.

evidence.note: Uses strict greater-than (>) instead of >= for the lower bound of A range. Problem specifies 'A: 90-100', meaning 90 should be included.

misconceptions.name: Extraneous code for different problem
misconceptions.description: Student includes code for calculating distance between two points (lines 7-16), which is completely unrelated to the grade calculator problem. This suggests the student either copied code from a different assignment or failed to properly clean their submission.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe this distance calculation code is needed for the grade calculator problem, or they may have accidentally included it from a previous problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The grade calculator problem requires only: reading one numeric grade input, applying conditional logic to determine the letter grade, and outputting the result. The distance calculation is completely unnecessary and unrelated.
symptoms: Irrelevant code that doesn't contribute to solving the stated problem
Class name 'DistanceBetweenPoints' doesn't match problem (should relate to grades)
Confusing mix of two different problems in one submission
Unnecessary variable declarations and calculations (x1, y1, x2, y2, distance)
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of template code or copy-paste error from a previous exercise. The student may not have properly reviewed their submission before submitting.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove all lines 7-16 (the distance calculation section). Keep only the grade input, conditional logic, and grade output. Also rename the class to something appropriate like 'GradeCalculator'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The distance calculation code is visibly unrelated to the grade calculator problem. The class name and the first 16 lines of code clearly belong to a different problem, while lines 18-30 address the actual Q3 requirement.

evidence.note: Entire distance calculation section is unrelated to the grade calculator problem. This appears to be leftover code from a different assignment.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect inclusive boundary for A grade (90 misclassified)
misconceptions.description: The condition for an 'A' grade uses grade > 90 instead of including 90, which causes a grade of 90 to be labeled as 'B' rather than 'A' as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can implement the A range of 90–100 using grade > 90 and the B range 80–89 using grade >= 80 in an if-else chain.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To match ranges like A: 90–100 and B: 80–89, the condition for A must include 90 (for example, grade >= 90) and the condition for B must exclude 90 (so that 90 does not fall into the B case). When translating inclusive numeric intervals into code, you must carefully choose >= or > so that shared boundaries like 90 go into the correct category.
symptoms: A numeric grade of 90 is classified as 'B' instead of 'A'.
The B range effectively becomes 80–90 instead of 80–89.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how to convert inclusive mathematical ranges (90–100, 80–89) into Java boolean expressions, especially at shared boundaries.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the conditions so that they directly reflect the ranges: e.g., if (grade >= 90) { A } else if (grade >= 80) { B } else if (grade >= 70) { C } etc. This ensures that 90 is included in A and excluded from B, matching the problem statement.
related_concepts: Translating mathematical intervals into boolean expressions
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The specification clearly defines A as 90–100 and B as 80–89, while the code uses grade > 90 for A and grade >= 80 for B, which unambiguously misclassifies a grade of 90.

evidence.note: Uses > 90 for 'A' while the problem states A: 90–100, B: 80–89, so 90 is incorrectly categorized as B.

misconceptions.name: Unnecessary code artifacts from previous tasks
misconceptions.description: The student left extraneous code unrelated to the current task (Q3 Grade Calculator) in the solution file, suggesting a common practice of modifying a previous solution instead of starting fresh, or simply failing to clean up.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable or irrelevant to keep code that solves previous problems (like the Distance Between Points calculation) mingled with the current solution, as long as the required functionality is present somewhere in the file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Submission files should generally contain only the code dedicated to solving the specified problem (Q3), unless explicitly instructed otherwise.
symptoms: Code unrelated to Q3 (Distance Calculator) is present in the main method.
Class name does not match the required task ('DistanceBetweenPoints' for 'Grade Calculator').
misconceptions.root_cause: Poor file management or code organization habits; potentially misunderstanding the scope of the current required task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always start a new file or delete unrelated code when beginning a new assignment part to ensure only the relevant solution is submitted.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The first 16 lines of the main method are dedicated to calculating distance, which is entirely irrelevant to Q3.

evidence.note: Large block of code (Distance Calculator) unrelated to the Grade Calculator problem.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Incorrect strict inequality for highest bound check (Grade A)
misconceptions.description: The student used `grade > 90` to determine an 'A' grade. This excludes the exact value of 90, which should be included in the A range (90-100).
misconceptions.student_belief: The grade 'A' starts only *after* 90, not including 90. Therefore, 90 should be handled by the next condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The specified range for 'A' is 90-100. The condition must be `grade >= 90` to correctly include 90.
symptoms: A numeric grade of 90 results in a 'B' instead of an 'A'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of '90-100' as strictly greater than 90, or careless translation of the boundary condition into code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the required grading scale and ensure that boundary values are included using the `>=` operator where appropriate.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The grading scale clearly states 90-100 is an A, but the code uses `grade > 90`.

evidence.note: Uses strict inequality (> 90) which incorrectly excludes 90 from the 'A' grade range.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Off-by-one boundary error on upper limit
misconceptions.description: The student uses a strictly greater-than condition (>) for the upper boundary of grade A instead of greater-than-or-equal (>=), incorrectly excluding the edge case of exactly 90.
misconceptions.student_belief: A grade requires strictly greater than 90 (i.e., 91 or above) to qualify for an A.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: According to the specification, A covers the range 90-100 inclusive, so the condition should be grade >= 90, not grade > 90. A grade of exactly 90 must be classified as A.
symptoms: A grade of exactly 90 is classified as B instead of A
The first condition fails to match the problem specification (90-100, not 91-100)
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between inclusive and exclusive boundaries. Students sometimes confuse the mathematical notation [90, 100] with strict inequality operators, or may be thinking of score thresholds as 'above 90' rather than 'at or above 90'.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace `if (grade > 90)` with `if (grade >= 90)` so that a grade of exactly 90 is correctly classified as A.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is clearly testing grade > 90, which directly contradicts the specification of 'A: 90-100'. This is explicit and unambiguous.

evidence.note: Condition uses > instead of >= for grade A, so a grade of 90 will not match this condition and will fall through to the B condition.
Specification clearly indicates A should include 90, but the student's condition excludes it.
